title: Pocket Printer Upgrade - hybrid roller slides

description.text:
This printer won't quite fit in your pocket, but it is very easy to take with you. I designed the printer around two constraints. First, the high mass motors and extruder are stationary. This allows smooth high speed printing, as only the print bed moves. This keeps the forces on the slides low as well. This will also allow dual extruders on a very lightweight printer. Second, the slides are all integrated, using PLA bearing surfaces running on the extrusions. I wanted to try this on all the axes of a printer since it works so well on my Aluminum Mendel. It is self-contained, with power supply on board. It is very robust, and makes top quality prints. I made this printer to test the above constraints, but it works so well I decided to publish it. The print volume is 120mm W x 100mm D x 65mm H. This could be expanded a little by getting longer extrusions. Pocket Printer on Marlin - http://youtu.be/lAwCmbKS-yQ
I have comb activated, so it travels around the cord cutout on this iPhone dock at a very rapid travel speed. Watch this printer and my Aluminum Mendel http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16076 print side by side here http://youtu.be/JysNv3Hi67k I posted a video at http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4tpOokI6_Z0
I wanted to see if it could print vertically. It is printing a stretchy bracelet - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13505. I hope this inspires others to expand on this design.

I added the controller with sd card reader and click encoder as seen in tommyc's excellent tutorial - http://tommyc-reprap.blogspot.com/2012/03/panelmax-tutorial.html. Now I can grab a coil of filament and the printer and print anywhere. This is printed in PLA. Drilling and tapping small parts is necessary to build this project. A drill press is nice, but it could be done by hand. The sliding surfaces fit well with my printer settings, but you can use a new, sharp file to remove a little material if necessary. Take your time with fitting the slides, a good fit without too much friction is needed. The x and y inner slides can be adjusted externally for a perfect fit. I use a very light film of silicone lube on the slides. I tried many different designs on the slides, but this one really works the best. The exploded view and BOM should provide enough info to make this project. I zipped the stl files because there are 22 total. I also zipped the entire Inventor project. I did not provide all the limit switch or power supply and switch mounts. 4/24/2012
I upgraded the slides to a hybrid roller version that is easy to print and assemble and has low friction and good precision. All the stl files are in the zipped folder. I was unsuccessful in simplifying the pulley arrangement by combining x and y movement, so I added a small, lightweight stepper for the x axis. This motor weighs only 4.9 ounces, compared to 12 for the standard steppers, so moving mass is still low. The motor should be run near its maximum current of 500 mA, so I recommend making the x motor mount out of aluminum plate to dissipate the heat. A drawing with dimensions is included in the zipped file. I also upgraded to the Misumi belts and pulleys. I think the smooth action is worth the extra cost. 4/27/2012
An exploded view drawing of the hybrid roller slide has been added below. The BOM is on the exploded view drawing.

comments.text: What distance should I raise the heated aluminum print bed plate from the PLA x-axis slider plate? I'm concerned the bed heater might warp the PLA x-axis plate.
comments.author: ronsheely

comments.text: Use at least 1" long screws to attach it.  It must be high enough so that the extruder will reach the bed when z is at minimum.  Heat will not be a problem at this height, at least with PLA bed temps.  I have very good luck with the aluminum/mirror print bed.  Be sure to ground the aluminum plate if using a 120 V heater.
comments.author: ronsheely

comments.text: I modified the x-axis slide assembly. The bearings pinch the y-axis rail far too tightly, and when I did manage to get the bearing posts to flex enough, the bearing posts that share the rail guides lift and rotate the guides enough to significantly bind the slider. There is a larger bending moment on these posts, because they are longer than the opposite posts. The opposite posts have to be shorter to clear the x-axis motor mount. I think the longer posts will always bend farther sooner than the shorter posts. I drilled out all four bearing fastener holes, and elongated the bearing mounting holes on the short posts, increasing the spacing between opposing bearings so that the overall pinching force is just enough to keep positive pressure against the rail. I used longer fasteners with locking nuts on the x-slide mount. It's temporary, until I can print an improvement.
comments.author: ronsheely

comments.text: The y-axis idler pulley appears to be about 5mm too high. It will not align with the y-axis belt. The 5mm offset is too much to cut from the end support, so I'm going to drill new blind extrusion holes in the end support, and drop the end support enough to bring the pulley back in line. I'll have to add 5mm pads to the rear feet to level the printer. Has anyone else run into this, or did I make a mistake in the assembly?
comments.author: ronsheely

comments.text: Your problems stem from changes I made to give you a larger print area.  I should not have made those changes without building them myself.  I think this printer is best used as its original design as a small, portable machine.
comments.author: ronsheely

comments.text: I think this is going to be a great printer. Little glitches like this are to be expected when operating on the cutting edge. Being able to create prototypes rapidly like this is a wonderful thing. Electronic systems became softer with programming. Then electronics itself became soft with programmable logic cell arrays. Now mechanical components are soft. Before long, we will be printing polymer transistors and carbon fibers. Yeah, rapid prototyping is cool.
comments.author: dkennell

comments.text: I started aligning the z-axis tonight. Do any of you have a favorite technique to align the z-axis? I'm still experimenting, but I made the following "obvious" observations.
comments.author: ronsheely

comments.text: To align the z axis I like to get it in about the right position by measuring.  Run the z all the way to the top, loosen the screws on the bearing bracket/handle and move to position where z screw moves freely. Ream holes in handle if nececcary.  Run z all the way to bottom and adjust motor.  Repeat if necessary. I have stopped using the spiral cut aluminum couplings because the last 5 I bought had the shaft hole bored out of alignment.  They all wobbled when installed on the motor without the leadscrew connected.  I use either the resin or alumunum couplers from Misumi with good results.  They have set screws which grip the leadscrew better than the clamp style.
comments.author: ronsheely

comments.text: I think I have the z-axis aligned now. My coupling may also be out of true, but other than that, the z-axis drive looks good to me.
comments.author: dkennell

comments.text: Thanks Dave. I'm starting to understand the z-axis. There are many more degrees of freedom than I first supposed. For example, the z-axis PLA motor mount has a large moment arm from the extrusion fasteners, to the motor shaft, so any non-flat protrusion from plastic "burrs", can tilt the threaded rod significantly.

comments.text: I discovered the source of the x-axis binding. It was not the bearing post spring force like I thought. I originally loosened the PLA guide fasteners to eliminate the guides as the source of the binding, assuming they floated, then "bore sighted" the length of the extrusion, looking for changes in the air gap. Tonight however, just to avoid butchering the slide unnecessarily, I tested the slide and bearings over a single rail, without the PLA guides, the slide inverted, flat on the bench. The slide moved freely (yahoo!). I feel silly for having missed something so obvious, but it was not obvious to me at the time. I think the bearing rims were breaking against the slides. The bearing, being typically out of round, exhibited near friction free movement for about 4 mm, until binding again. Dave, I think you invented a really cool miniature break pad. Keep that filed away. I'm sure we'll need it someday.
comments.author: dkennell

comments.text: I'm still having trouble with the x-axis binding. I can tweak the rail guides and get smooth action, but after a couple test slides, the assembly jams. I still think the rails are acting like break pads because the bearing post spring force is too high.

comments.text: I have a few questions about the print bed.
comments.author: ronsheely

comments.text: Kapton on an aluminum bed with a silicone heat pad underneath has worked well for me.  It is expensive, and easily damaged.  The seams do leave small mark.  My vendor has always been Ultimachine.  I saw a suggestion a few weeks ago for printing on a mirror.  It seemed like the metallic coating could help heat transfer between the aluminum plate and the glass.  A local hardware store cut me a few pieces, but I never really tried it until tonight. The results of a few small print jobs were quite good, so I may use this for a while.  It is a perfect durable surface, and with the mirror you can really see the first layer as it is going down.  I clipped it to my bed with some binder clips.  I have also tried a piece of plexiglass from a storm door.  The part stuck so hard I could hardly get it off.  Maybe it would work if it were not heated.  The glass definitely adds mass, so we'll see how it works on some faster prints.
comments.author: ronsheely

comments.text: Thanks Dave. A mirror? Sounds innovative, clever. Got t' love this open source community.

comments.text: Extending 50 mm on all axes sounds wise.  I did modify the x slide for you and made the tabs longer.  The way I set up the build plate, the mounting screws are outside the normal print envelope.  Therefore, the space between the screws is longer than the Y travel.  You might be able to make a different style mount that would get around this limitation.  I had never planned to make this a true reprap, one that could reproduce itself.  Adding that constraint didn't make sense.  All I wanted was a very compact, portable printer.  If you want a larger printer eventually, you small printer could print an Aluminum Mendel, everything but the vertical braces.
comments.author: ronsheely

comments.text: I am anxiously waiting for the new BOM! lol  I purchased all of the extrusions so far.  I'm making my build area a little larger so I can take advantage of the Prusa PCB HBP.  Is the X axis motor a NEMA 17 or 14?  If 17, what is the torque on a small motor like that?
comments.author: Entropy85

comments.text: I'll work on the documentation this weekend.  The x motor is a NEMA 14, from Pololu -  #1208.  It is 28 mm high with 14 oz-in holding torque (compared to 44 oz-in for the standard motors).  You might want to use the Pololu #1209 which is 36 mm high with 20 oz-in holding torque with your larger platform.  That motor weighs 1.4 oz more, but is still about half the weight of the standard motor.  You would have to increase the height of the feet 10mm to have clearance for the larger motor.
comments.author: Entropy85

A coworker of mine who loves 3D printed squirrels is traveling abroad for a few months. Not wanting her to be squirrel-less in her travels, I did a bit of jiggery pokery on an existing model to come up with the profile.

Special thanks to the original model creator MBCook as this is a work of beauty that I have printed many times over the past couple of years.

print_settings.Notes:: 10% Infill worked best for me.

description.text:
he 3D Maze V3 - Designed by Hendrik Koopmans
It is based on an article from Scientific American September 1988.
The present design of the maze inclusive the „actuator“ structure is by me.
This version is a remix of the V2 version.
The knobs are bigger to enable „smoother“ movement.
The maze is slightly more complex.

The object is to move the "actuators" from one corner to the other.
You have to figure out that a possible movement in one dimension can be blocked in the next one.

Printer:

Da Vinci Mini w

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Printer Brand: Da Vinci
Printer: Mini w
Rafts: No
Supports: no for the top. Yes for the box.
Resolution: 0.2mm
Infill: 10%

Notes:
Warping can be a problem! I 2heated the printing area with a 200W lamp, because my bed is not heated.

  • 10% Infill worked best for me.

  • 0.2 mm layer height.

  • Try out the best settings for yourself.

Final assembly is a bit tricky. Assemble the actuators and then glue the panels together one by one. Insert the actuator structure after you have glued 2 panels together.
In the end glue the knobs on the actuators in such way that a smooth movement is possible (try out before you apply glue).

When you build the box at once plus the top panel. Assemble the actuators inside the box and then glue the top panel.

I sprayed the box with clear polyurethane lacker.

Actuator assembly Actuator assembly, but assemble inside the box. (A leg of one actuator is temporarily cut and glued again together

Belt tensioner for the long belts. The wave shape is designed to minimize point stress as in other designs.

loosen pullies before installing, then realign the X and Y axis.
The belts for the Y axis are a bit more difficult to install than the X axis. It's important to put the open side pointing inwards, otherwise they will run against the sliding blocks.

comments.text: Anet A8 => Works well with scale 1.3
comments.author: onilink

comments.text: Works awesome!  Even printed on a new [non-Ultimaker]  machine build with a less than proper Y belt tension.  All is good now thanks to this fix. Cheers.
comments.author: BearCNC

comments.text: It will actually fit on the y belt of my wanhao 3d printer
comments.author: destruction1791

comments.text:
Nice idea, didn't test it yet but I'm sure it will help as my printer has a quite basic system for fixing its belt and it's really hard to get them tight.
Just one little thing, the .stl is little botched and my printer (using cura slicer) prints it in a quite bad way. Check the wireframe and you'll see.
Great and nice that you provided the source though, I just advise people who are able to read the file to re-export it themselves.
Thanks for this neat part :)
comments.author: JJJpnt

comments.text: Nice design, but won't work on the X-belt on the Tronxy 802/Anet A8. It hits the extruder. Works fine on the Y-belt.

comments.text: Thank you! Greatly improved the tension on my Prusia i3 x axis

comments.text: Basically you need to release one of the pullies for each belt before you can install them, otherwise you create more tension in one side of the belt. Have you done this?

comments.text: dont have a clue how to do that
comments.author: Gijs

comments.text:
Are you sure that your belts aren't tight enough? Which ultimaker do you have and how old is it? On a newer ultimaker original I have, they are not necessary, neither on ultimaker 2.
If it's old and they need more tension, then just loosen the set screw in one pully with a hex screwdriver provided with your ultimaker, put the tensioner on and retighten the set screw.

comments.author: Gijs

comments.text: you can't really break the printer. It's meant to be a maintainable printer. If however you are not confident, I'd recommend you find some fellow Ultimaker users in your neighbourhood to help you out. But it isn't really that difficult. If you read through the link I sent of the XY axes, you will see that it isn't that hard. It's only one screw you have to temporarily loosen per belt.

description.text:
-If you think you want to help bring this to life you can either donate or, make it and contact me for recommended improvements.

This is a 6020 (Will do 4020 in the future) V-Slot Resin 3d Printer. It requires 1 extrusion part can be easily adjusted to your needs to changing length of the aluminium profile, rods and lead screw. The Z axis carriage can be single or double (like in picture) for adding a second motor on the back if you are planing to make a bigger version. All m5 holes are in grid to match V-Slot rails in both Horizontal and Vertical. Also another feature I am planing to add on the design is the ability to replace the arm with a V-Slot bracket that can fit 2 towers together for an XL version of the machine (i want to give the ability to easily scale this project to everyone needs by printing more parts and choosing the corresponding length of rods/lead scew/V-Slot).

Base Part that holds V-Slot is inspired by D-BOT XY carriage, V-Slot joints, originally designed by spauda01
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1001065

Platform Holder is from Cristelia - Open Source LCD SLA resin printer designed from Krzysztof Dymianiuk a.k.a. dvjcodec
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1680172/

Parts: (Quantitly depends on configuration and scale of the build)

1-2 x V-Slot
2-4 x 12mm Linear Rod
2-8 x LM12UU Bearing
1-4 x 8MM Acme Lead Screw + T Nut
1-4 x 5mm to Coupler
1-4 x Nema 17

Updates/Notes/Upcoming Changes

  1. The Cover now have the holes to mount on Base part. Still need to add more holes and mount holes for electronics maybe add a fan as well. (In progress)

  2. I started designing the tilt mechanism. Will be consisted of 2 cheap RC Servo motors and some 3d printed parts. (In Progress)

  3. Need to design a vat that will work with the tilt mechanism.

  4. I am planing tomake a 4020 Version for very small builds.

  5. I am planingto add the base.stp with different diameter holes for linear rods. Starting from 8mm-12mm.

Current configurations:

comments.text: Is there an easy way to determine what projector to use based on the size of the build volume?
comments.author: fractalmfg

comments.text: I designed this to be as adjustable as possible. For z you choose longer aluminium profile length. For bigger X,Y you setup/choose your light source accordingly. If you want to go for a to big build and worried that the platform will tilt then you can print 2 Z axis and connect them with the brackets. If you think the weight will be to much you can add a second motor etc.
comments.author: fractalmfg

comments.text: I understand. I'm asking more about how to determine the largest XY a projector will support?
comments.author: Kldz

comments.text: you will have to do some tests with your projector. I only designed the mechanical so far, but there are resources on the internet for software and for light sources.
comments.author: fractalmfg

comments.text: I'm not sure if this is helpful but the model here is meant for an LCD based projection source (i.e. LCD panel is placed under the build area and a high power LED shines through it (effectively using the LCD as a Mask) curing the liquid resin. Today this works with Daylight Resins but there are threads where people are testing LCDs in the hopes of finding a UV resin solution.
comments.author: fractalmfg

description.text:
Update: Some more tweaking and added a piggy-back for my Turbo2, since I had already routed charging and audio cables to the dash from before. If anyone would like my poor workflow Fusion 360 version, drop a comment and I'll add it.

With Android Auto v2 going self-contained, I found I really liked it, but my Turbo2 was just too small of a screen. Got hip to Head Unit Reloaded which acts an AA head unit emulator, which was just what I needed to put my old Nexus 7 (2012) to use. Modified my original device holder my shortening the shaft and lengthening the arms.

I recommend printing in PETG if you'll leave it in when not in use.

Make a custom wireless gamepad with Cherry MX Switches! In this project, we'll build a custom PCB for Cherry MX switches and the Adafruit Feather 32u4 Bluefruit LE to make a custom gamepad. We'll design and 3D print an enclosure and custom keycaps. This project is great for casual gaming, or creating custom controllers for various applications.

description.text:
Cute tiny enclosure for the great Micro Word Clock by Daniel Rojas.
https://github.com/formatc1702/Micro-Word-Clock

The microcontroller and LEDs are powered by 3x AG13/LR44 alkaline batteries, which are very common and cheap and a CR1220 is used for the real time clock.

I used this pushbutton:
http://www.ebay.de/itm/100Pcs-Push-Button-Tact-Switch-4-Pin-Smd-Micro-Switch-6-6-2-5Mm-Tactile-Switch-P-/331928441992?hash=item4d487a1488:g:-YwAAOSwKOJYIZ5N

And a single DIP switch is used as a power switch:
http://www.ebay.de/itm/10pcs-2-54mm-Red-Pitch-Slide-Type-DIP-Switch-1-Bit-2-Bit-3-Bit-4-Bit-5-Bit-6-Bit-/331311690635?var=&hash=item4d23b7338b:m:mpc81MzzplMLqZs9QUWzF5w

I added a schottky diode for reverse polarity protection, which was soldered directly to the switch.

For the LR44s these battery holders were used (trimmed a little using scissors):
http://www.ebay.de/itm/Metal-AA-Battery-Spring-Contact-Lamination-Plate-Terminal-Silver-Tone-30pcs-/121938564123?hash=item1c641ad41b:g:MPYAAOSwPCVX~xga

For the CR1220 i made 2 simple contacts out of tin.

As an extension for the pushbutton a M2 bolt was used which was cut to size after the device was finished (you can see it sticking out of the back cover.

2 tiny 1.5mm plastic screws out of some scrap electronics device were used to hold the back cover in place.

description.text:
This is a GoPro compatible Mount for TomTom Bandit Action Cam.

I printed this part with 0.8mm shell thickness, 0.1mm layer height and 100% infill layers with PETG and it seems quite strong and functional. I print the top and bottom components separately and glue them together, also included a complete part however my the result after printing the complete part with support was not to my satisfaction. You might have a better result.

To ensure a proper clip on of the camera you may need to clean the overhang's of the camera mounting bracket with a sharp knife post printing. I would not recommend a 3D printed part in use cases where the camera can potentially be harmed should the printed part fail. However for tripod or other non extreme uses these parts should be sufficient.

I used a little adhesive foam tape to complete the part, however this did not even seem necessary.

"Zou Bisou Bisou..." -Megan Draper Add a 1:16 scale Nelson Marshmallow sofa to your Madiverse (Mad Men + Thingiverse) http://bit.ly/madiverse Roger needs this in his office! The premiere of Mad Men was a tasty appetizer for the season of change ahead!

1a. Print one of this file:
  • Nelson_Marshmallow_Sofa_Mounts_Plate.stl
    • 1b. Print two of these files:

  • Nelson_Marshmallow_Sofa_Marshmallows_Plate.stl

  • Nelson_Marshmallow_Sofa_Frame.stl

  • Once printed, the mounting holes in the marshmallows should be tight and allow for a friction fit, but it may it may be necessary to slightly enlarge them. Use a pin vise with the correct drill bit to do so. CA/super glue will likely be required to affix them to the mounts.

  • The full-size sofa comes in many finishes, e.g., silver frame with black marshmallows, black frame with red marshmallows, etc. If you don't have the correct color filament, print with natural/white filament and use spray paint or permanent marker to color the finished print prior to assembly.

  • Test fit parts and use CA glue to affix them. Suggested assembly order:
    • i. Glue marshmallows onto mounts. Pay attention to orientation and distance of marshmallows from mount. ii. Position completed mounted marshmallows onto frames. Ensure that marshmallow mounts are not too far nor too close to each other (small pieces of tape are helpful to hold mounts in place while viewing from different angles). iii. Once positioned, use CA glue to attach long mounts to frame. iv. Finally, position and glue short mounts to frame. Take your time, work slowly, and reposition/re-glue as needed. It took several positioning and gluing attempts to assemble the pictured sofa correctly.

This is the same "Gravity Screw" but separated into two STL files. Note that YOU CAN NOT ASSEMBLE THIS AFTER PRINTING! You must assemble them in your software and print as a single print out. The main reason I did this is so that people with dual extruders or other setups can treat the STL models separately.

if you want a easy single STL file to print, go to the original project. This version is more so you can set the files up differently.  
Load each STL file into your software.  
Center the nut around the bolt making sure the threads line up.  They should be correct from the beginning the the main need it to get the centering right.  
If you have a dual extruder, you can set a different color for each part.  
if you scale in the Z direction, be sure to scale the nut the same amount.  
Print it.

author: mrm64

description.text:
IMPORTANT UPDATE: This model is prone to overheating in its current state. For anybody making this, I recommend avoiding hot glue, and instead using super glue or some other non-heat-sensitive bonding agent. I also recommend removing the lid if you intend to leave the lamp on for longer than 15 minutes (right now the lid cuts off circulation and creates a small LED powered oven). I am in the process of redesigning the lid/lamp body to accommodate for this issue. While I am at it, I will also look into figuring out how to make the lamp spin.

Update 2: I have finished designing version 2.0, and am currently in the process of printing. If all goes well, the new design should be up by the end of the month.

Version2: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2235504

This lamp holds and displays lithophane tiles. Each of the 4 sides can hold 75x150mm worth of lithophanes. You can get creative with that, but I only printed 3 easy to work with sizes, which were 75x50, 75x75, and 75x100. Feel free to mix and match, as the tiles are easy to move around and replace.

In the finished picture above I have one side with the lithophane tiles turned out, and one with them turned in. The turned in side was a fair bit less detailed, but I would wager that tweaking the settings when printing could remedy that.

I used Cura to create the lithophanes and the settings I used were:

  • Height: 4mm
  • Base: 0.6mm
  • Width: 75mm
  • Depth: (anything <= 150mm)
  • Darker is higher
  • No smoothing

The LEDs I used were these: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01LXX3AP4/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s02?ie=UTF8&psc=1

For more information, I wrote up a quick and messy blog about it here: http://walker-tech-studio.tumblr.com/tagged/lithophane

If I left anything out, let me know!

remixed_from.author: nw15062
remixed_from.title: HTCVive Bracket for Welding headgear mod.

description.text:
An adaptation of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1620362 adapter. Basically a rework of it but credit given for the idea and clip design.

This adapter is designed specifically for the http://www.northerntool.com/shop/tools/product_200659536_200659536 welding helmet liner from Northern Tool which is currently under $10. It may work fine for other liners as well but as always it may not.

Print two of the brackets. I used a new to me PLA filament I'm testing that prints really well for me and my printer from a company clled BAMtack!. I think the ! in the name is a bit much but it prints just as well for me as any other filament including Hatchbox, eSun, MeltInk3D (another test that turned out really well). Filament choices are pretty nice these days.

Take the front strap off the helmet liner. Remove the cushion piece, it just velcros on and you can attach it to the top welding strap. Note the top welding strap is adjustable for length. You may need to adjust it to get it to sit higher or lower on your head as needed.

Unscrew the side knobs on the liner. Remove the flat spacer and discard from each one. Remove the other thicker spacers and reserve. Add the brackets to the screw post so that the slot on the end is closer to the inside of the liner. Add the fat spacers back and put then nut back on.

Between the slot in the brackets and the slot in the welding liner where the screw holds everything together you should have plenty of range of adjustment to move the HMD forward or backward to fit the smallest or fattest heads.

Slide the two elastic side straps out of the D rings holding them to the HMD. Just angle the rubber piece on each end of the straps a little and with just a little pressure you can slide them out at an angle.

Snap the 3d printed bracket on to the D ring on the HMD using the slot at the front. Now take 4 m3x10 screws and screw them into the 4 holes on the brackets making sure the D ring is fully seated. These bolts should go through the D ring and secure the HMD to the brackets. No nuts are needed, the screws will bite into the print and hold it secure. Do NOT OVERTIGHTEN!!!

Take your two side straps from the HMD and you can wrap them around the strap on the helmet liner and secure them to theirselves quite nicely and provide more strappage to keep the helmet secure.

Unlike in the picture here, you may want to unsnap the top strap of the helmet liner and run the top strap of the HMD under it instead of over it like in the picture.

Press down on the back knob and twist it to open the liner strap all the way.

Drop the whole contraption on your head and press down and twist the knob on the back to tighten things back up.

In playing with it I've found the HMD is now rock solid on my big melon, I can look up, down without any shifting at all. Super vigorous activity may cause some bouncing but until we have a socket in the back of our skulls feeding directly into the brain I'm not sure it's possible to comfortably eliminate all possible movement of a device strapped to your face.

I'm marking this as a WIP as I want to design and print another pair of brackets to allow the use of another elastic strap that would sit below the 'hump' in the back of the head to add even more support to get more weight off the face.

Printer:

MendelMax 3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.25 or whatever you like

Infill:

10% or whatever you like

Notes:

I printed mine at 10%, with 3 layers and 2 perimeters. THe brackets seem strong enough you're going to destroy the HMD about the same time you add enough force to break the brackets. YMMV and if you're concerned then up the perims to 3 and the infil to 30%

Supports may or may not be necessary depending on your printer. I find them useful. They make sure the slot in the bracket is nice and clean and are easy pried out with a pick or just a knife would work.

comments.text: Made it and haven't tested it out yet however it fits quite well!
comments.author: rodsawhite

comments.text: Works great!
comments.author: longdong

comments.text: I just printed your brackets for my vive. First print installed and works incredible. Such a cheap mod and it makes a HUGE difference to the vive. Now I need to order 6mm VR Cover Memory Foam to get more FOV.
comments.author: krazycanuck2011

comments.text: Regarding the FOV, I took the narrow face foam that came with the vive and used a razor knife to thin it down about 1/3rd in thickness and that worked well for getting a bit more FOV out of the vive.   This was before there were commercial options.
comments.author: krazycanuck2011

comments.text: Glad it worked out for you.  Me and the kids have found it much more secure.   Funnily enough I just saw a CES report yesterday where there's what appears to be multiple over the counter options coming that do exactly this.  Some were even obviously 3d printed mockups based on the layer lines on them in the videos I saw.
comments.author: krazycanuck2011

comments.text: Yeah I saw the deluxe set too. I am sure its comfortable but I would guess the price is over $200 for sure. I am eyeballing the tracker and the wireless solutions pending the lag....

Fencing for 28mm wargaming. I have versions with and without barbed wire posts. These print very nicely with no supports. I may add a latch to the gate, but I don't know that it's needed. I intend to add in a shorter fence as well in the near future.

description.text:
My version of a poor man's bucket garden.
I designed this garden, because I could not find a garden that was small enough for my boat. And I like fresh herbs in my food. :)
I design it, in Fusion360. and i 3d printed on a Flash Forge dreamer.

Parts you need to print.

3 center column
1 top center column
1 top lid
9 Net pot’s
3 plug’s
1 water level plug
1 water fixtur
4 1 to 4 bucket_garden_bucket_captop
4 1 to 4 bucket_garden_bucket_cap

Parts you need to buy.

1 standad bucket
1 Mini DC 12V 5W IP68 Waterproof Ultra-quiet Micro Brushless Water Oil Pump W3Y1
1 clear tube Ø3 mm 1 meter

Im using simplfy 3D with this settings. (PLA)
100% infil
6 top and bottom solid layers
outline overlap 50%
Support pillar 1,5 mm (only on net pot and center column)
Temperatur on heatbed 60 and Left extruder 210

Glue water fixtur to top column, and 1 to 4 bucket_garden_bucket_captop to
1 to 4 bucket_garden_bucket_cap.
The Diameter of the cap for the bucket.

The bucket i’m using is 294 mm inner diameter, so the lip on
the cap is 294 mm and the outer diameter is 320 mm. (See Figur 1.)

But you can make the "bucket cap" out of acrylic or wood, if you like. And save some printing time.

title: Knuckle Coupler for LGB
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Updated Oct 2017: I have added the "fixed 7 degree" version of my revised geometry couplings here. These are single piece parts, and need the lock ring to push them down firmly in the housings. It has similar "push" performance to the two part version and they do interlock, but the single piece geometry is designed to work "optimally" with
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2553019.

The two piece parts were originally revised 27 Feb 2017 to provide better "push" performance, because I discovered that my original design had a fault when "pushing" a long train. When the coupling is subject to strong push forces, the old design allows the coupling to open. . (I have added a picture to show four coupled together with me pushing them together. You can see the left (old) coupling opening, whilst the right (new) coupling remains in line)
The new "push" versions has a very small additional feature on the knuckle, which engages with the opposite knuckle in push mode and holds the two together better. I have also very slightly increased the spring strength.

It has been designed to work with LGB and LGB type models fitted with the "LGB peg". The strange cut outs in the housings are there to allow it to fit without having to modify the train or coaches.
Once fitted, it sits below the central LGB buffer on the Coaches, but the Central buffer on the Stainz loco is larger and has to be removed. This is a press fit part, so the process is fully reversible if you wish to return to hook and eye couplers later.

This design differs from Raby's original design in that the "hook" is now above the "tang", and so this design cannot use the iron bar type decoupling. However, the "Hook" eye is now fitted directly to the LGB peg on the train model, so should transfer loads well. I have tested one version at about 1.5kg pull and it survived. (27-02-2017.. See also my comments on pushing)

It has been tested to fit the LGB Stainz loco, and the coaches from the standard starter set. It has been tested pulling this around standard R1 curves, and up and down on a garden railway.

There is a small hole in the "peg" part of the main body that you can use to screw a screw into the ""peg" on the coach if you want ultimate strength, but I have not used this so far.
The photos show a slightly earlier version, with a "knob" on the end of the spring. This actually limited side to side movement a bit, so I have removed it in the final version.

In the photo, the coach and Loco are fitted with my electrical connection, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1023944

Printer:

Mini Kossel

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

35%

Notes:

This must be printed in ABS.
The main body needs to be printed with support type "Everywhere", so that the overhang prints nicely. Although the "overhang (upper) part of the main body is not structural, it holds the parts together when assembling, and helps align the body with the LGB peg on the train/coach when fitting to the train. The Support structures will need care when removing. I have only rarely got them out in one piece. Using a flat head screwdriver and levering out from the sides seems the most successful way to get the main support out.
The knuckle is printed in two parts, with the small bottom part being glued to the upper part after printing. I use Acetone and it glues ABS very well, but I am not sure the extra part is actually necessary, as the coupling works fine without it.
Once printed, the eyes of the tang and hook should be reamed out to give a good fit. I use a 8mm rat tail file and gradually advance the eye down the file, whilst rotating the file. You can get an excellent circular fit this way.
I also give the top surface of the main "bar" section of the tang and hook a quick file, so that they slide smoothly against each other.
To assemble, simply slot the "tang" in first, then the "Knuckle" should slide in and partially engage with the peg in the main body. It will then align with and held by the peg on the coach when you assembly it to the coach.

Using 123D

I designed this in 123D, but started with a Step file of Raby's original design. (thank you!)
I have added 0.75mm to the face of the tang to make the coupling a bit "tighter", but this may be unnecessary.

comments.text:
Hello,
Printed on my MendelMax 1.5 with 20% infill and .25 layer height. After reorienting with cad software to be edge down, printed in 5.5 hrs for both pieces on one plate. Only item is that the 2 pieces do not fit snug together and since I printed in black I used some black electrical tape around bottom rim to provide snug fit. Thank you for the print I really like it otherwise

comments.text: I believe my original slic3r settings were 5 perimeters minimum and a layer height of 0.4.  My printer is a printrbot plus.  My extrusion multiplier may have been dialed down at the time to 0.98 or so.  I used PLA plastic.  Slip fit printing is tough to calibrate and Porting it to another printer could take a few tests.  I'm actually glad it worked as well for you as it sounds it did.  When starting this project, get some sandpaper and print a half inch to an inch of both pieces, sand smooth and test the fit.  If it's too tight is how you'll want the pieces to come out, so that you can smooth the surface and remove material with sanding.  Thanks for the feedback.

author: d7071

description.text:
These brackets are designed to mount 8mm lead screws to the MakerFarm Pegasus. I have the 10" version with metal motor mounts and X-carriage, so I haven't been able to test it on other sizes, but looking at pictures it should work fine. I'd be interested to hear feedback though.

I originally purchased the ACME Lead Screw Upgrade kit from Colin at MakerFarm but there were a few things I didn't like about it:

  1. The provided nut blocks are very snug and don't spin easily, even after over a month of use and running it through a drill as recommended.
  2. The Pegasus' X-axis extrusions aren't log enough to mount the nut blocks correctly without the awkward and frustrating extensions.
  3. The nut blocks are mounted so low on the X-axis that they nearly hit the motor coupler when the Z-axis is at Z0. This caused some weird Z ringing at lower print heights on my printer since it's hard to get the lead screws perfectly vertical.

This mod uses 8mm brass lead screw nuts to try and fix all of the above. I used these, but there are tons just like it on Amazon and eBay.

If your printer is still using 5mm threaded rods you can still upgrade to lead screws using this mod, you'll just need to source the following:

  • 8mm lead screws and nuts (I recommend ~400mm for the 10" Pegasus)
  • 8mm to 5mm flexible coupler

It'll probably end up being cheaper than purchasing the MakerFarm kit.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

50+%

Assembly

The lead screw nuts mount to the bracket using 3x3mm bolts with a lock nut. The bracket mounts to the top of the x-axis vslot rail using 2x5mm bolts and 2x t-slot nuts. Keep them loose until you left the lead screw perfectly and then tighten them down.

Note: I had to swap the direction of the bolts on the delrin wheels that hold the x-axis to the z-axis. I probably just did this wrong when I built it, but you may run into it as well.

comments.text: Its all about personal experience. I have had a nightmare working with one motor driving two rods. I threw out a $400 printer kit because it didnt work. Now i run a wall of 10 Makerfarm Pegasus 12s. Best printer ever in my opinion. I also have a question. Do you have to change anything in the firmware?
comments.author: DreamSpace

comments.text: You'll only have to change the steps per mm for the Z-axis, which will depend on the lead screw that you buy.
comments.author: DreamSpace

comments.text: Do they tell you the value to put in with the ones you buy?
comments.author: jlarsenwy

comments.text:
Some of them do, but you can figure out the exact value by using the prusa calculator under "leadscrew driven systems":
http://www.prusaprinters.org/calculator/
comments.author: DreamSpace

comments.text: Hi, I was planning on doing this upgrade from the 5mm rods, buying the parts you linked in the description. Do I also need to buy the DRV8825 driver normally included in the upgrade kit or would the A4988 driver be suitable? Thanks for the help!
comments.author: ewy87

comments.text: No issue with A4988 for me.  the nut blocks in the kit (open builds) are snug until they're used a bit so can be tight. these ones, the brass ones are not. long as both are aligned so they don't bind, it's fine.   i can run mine at 20mm/s up/down.   though i do use a titan with a 18-20cm stepper....
comments.author: ewy87

comments.text: Cool thanks for the info!
comments.author: diigbluh

comments.text: I wouldn't say it's required, but it is recommended.  The lead screws require a little more torque to drive, and the DRV8825 can output more power than the A4988's.  I've seen people run it just fine with the A4988's though as long as you increase the current.  I recommend adding a cooling fan to your RAMPs board if you do.  Make sure you check your stepper motors once in a while to make sure they aren't getting too hot.
comments.author: ewy87

comments.text: Ok sweet! I think I'll just get the DRV8825, no sense in not getting it if I have to start buying fans to make up for it. Thanks for the advice!
comments.author: jlarsenwy

comments.text: And always the same basic mistake ! two Z motors plus flexible couplings ! From awfully bad (M5 rods) to not very good in fact. Why not do the right thing directly ????
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: And I suppose your design is the "right" way?  While your upgrade is clever and may have some benefits, tons of manufactured and open-source printers use a 2-motor design with great success.  This Thing is a simple upgrade that provides a modest quality improvement for a specific printer, and it's certainly not "wrong".  Go take your ego somewhere else.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: An error repeated over and over still remains an error !
comments.author: jlarsenwy

comments.text: You're a dick. Stop being a dick. Try being constructive or educational instead of using ALL CAPS and making ASSERTIONS without any facts.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: he's a dick but correct.... those flexible couplers suck hard. also if you keep measuring after prints or use a dial gauge you'll see two motors can get out of sync/alignment.   it can be worse if you got z-hop which can do it 100's of times per print.   Actually the M5 rods may of been better since they also have a smaller pitch, error is spread over a larger distance.   everyone is using 8 MM pitched rods (4 starts * 2mm pitch = 8mm per 200 steps)... that's a huge.  2mm or 4mm would be better for vertial use.  acme rods like these are for linear motion but the Z barely moves and it's fighting against gravity.     Ideally you want to land on full steps with layer heights, if you calculate 8mm pitch rods (with the  prusa calculator), you get error at 0.1 and 0.3 layer heights.  you gotta use 0.12 or 0.28 instead.   reason is it's just more accurate using full steps since that's where the most holding torque will be and avoid microstepping errors.    using 4mm pitch with the rods right into the steppers like mk2 solves most issues except the sync thing.

These are most if not all parts I used/collected/designed to build my Logresse P3steel derivated 3d printer. Find out all about these ingeniously designed machines on https://www.logre.eu/wiki/Logresse. This one really is a "monster" as its name states. Most of the credits must go to the marvelous guys at Logre and the people mentioned below.
If needed I could upload the modified Marlin firmware for the ramps 1.4 board with the bed leveling support and the rrd fan extender board support which is needed for the dual extruder setup to get everything working. (I just didn't do it right now yet because I'm still experimenting with the bed leveling range to get it just right)
As for the parts I designed feel free to use / modify them. the other parts will have to be used as is or you have to ask permission to their respective owners. I upload everything as a bundle so you don't have to search/design every single part as I had to do.
I used a gtx LCD Smart Controller 12864 which has the sd slot on the right , but the normal one should work as well I think if you mirror the part. For all parts designed too be used on the left and right side, just mirror them and it should work ok.
The Z-top has to be drilled with a 5mm drill bit to minimize the use of support material. Most parts should be designed so no support is needed anyway.
Enjoy building !!!!

Please credit all people below for making this build possible:

  • The bowden extruders are from 3Dator http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1318849 and work wonderfully well. (Why reinvent if perfect)
  • The filament holders and are remixed from the ones available on the LOGRE website.
  • The vis/bidon and power protection casing parts are available on the LOGRE website (Why reinvent if perfect)
  • The switch case and the x-endstop are by Toolson http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1054909/#files (Why reinvent if perfect)
  • The lcd case is remixed from the one by Ghiotto http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:665671
  • The flexible Z-coupling is by Scratchrobot (tough not used by me anymore on this build, still a very good alternative for the real deal) http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:126971
    (I used it in the building phase until the aluminium one came in)
  • The GT20 gear is by PrinzThomas (tough not used by me anymore on this build, still a very good alternative for the real deal) http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:436038
    ((I used it in the building phase until the aluminium one came in)
  • The anti-wobble/anti backlash is a remix from the one by Jamesarm97 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:141479

PS: If you are the owner of one of these parts and you wish them removed from this project, please contact me and I will remove them as soon as possible or mention your name to receive all credits for your work.

description.text:
Simple router base centering cone.

Just use a piece of 1/4 round rod and this print to perfectly center your router base plate for use with pattern bushing.

Printer:

Anet A8 (Prusa i3)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Printed with Maker Geeks Raptor PLA @ 230c, bed @ 60c. No supports needed.

Tune center hole

Fit is critical so the center hole is a tad small. Just drill it to a perfect fit with a 1/4 drill bit. Also chuck up the 1/4 rod in your drill and sand lightly to get a nice slip fit with no play.

Fusion 360

Fusion 360

  1. created sketch and extruded center shaft upwards
  2. created fin sketch and extruded (symmetric) used circular pattern to revolve around shaft (new bodies)
  3. create cone profile sketch and revolved around center (new body)
  4. used shell tool to hollow the cone
  5. added chamfers

print_settings.Notes:: Supports are needed for the body, but not for the wings (they print flat).

description.text: This is a planter based on the Star Wars TIE fighters

Printer:

Fusion3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Supports are needed for the body, but not for the wings (they print flat).

I printed the body with gray filament and the wings with black, and then painted the windows and lines.

I also recommend printing with ABS plastic (PLA might not hold up when watered) and then spraying the inside with clear-coat spray paint (the kind with acetone in it)...this will make it waterproof, so that water only drains from the small hole at the bottom.

I based the design of this on "TIE fighter planter" by feverdreamt, but I recreated it from scratch. I designed it so that the body and wings could be printed separately (saving a lot of time and plastic from supports). I used Tinkercad for the entire design process.

description.text:
This is a work in progress to make a hinge compatible with raisers from Ikea Lack raiser and window holder

It's heavily inspired by Lack Table Enclosure Parts, but redesigned from the ground.

This is a first try with Tinkercard after 15 years without doing any 3D modeling, so expect some improvements ;-)

The inner part of the hinge is a little bit loosy because it's 1mm smaller than the outer part as I didn't found a way to model shapes with decimal measurements with Tinkercad.

I did not remixed hinge from this thing as I wanted to be able to remove the window easily.

This will fit M4 screws.

title: Hot End J-Head Bowden Filament Guide

description.text:
I had some cheap chinese J-Head Bowden Hot-Ends lying around. Problem always was to get the Filament in, because there is a gap between the heatsink and Bowden tube connector. So I designed this little spacer (I call it spacer ;-) ). Fits right between the heatsink and Bowden connector so the Filament can go easily inside the Hot-End. Works very good.
Please try out how this fits, There are two versions (2,2mm hole and 2mm hole). Maybe you need to rescale it....

Printer:

Kossel XL

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,05

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Print in finest Layer high you can go. Depending on which side you print you need Support or not. Because this is a small part print slow and with cooling on.

After print

Maybe you need to sand it a bit. Try out if it fits, if not rescale the part. Because of this I made two different Versions. One with 2.0mm hole for Filament and one with 2.2mm hole. Sure you also could drill the hole...
Autodesk Fusion 360

comments.text: sure you are right, but it won´t be printed... ;-)
comments.author: P_K_3PDK

comments.text:
A far better and easier solution is to drill the quick connect to 4 and install a piece of 2X4Teflon tubing.
One rule, filament better rides in or on PTFE or better. And it is cheap.
For a Bowden, just extend the tube.

title: 3D printer filament Spool Support
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I designed this simple thing to fit inside filament spools with an inner diameter around 53mm. It has one hole in the center too to fit the threaded rod from the Anet A8 filament holder. The outer diameter is 54mm and provides a nice tight fit. The diameter of the inner hole is 8.5mm. This print consumes very little filament, but is very strong and gets the job done.

title: Pi Camera mount for D-Bot Core XY

description.text:
This is my design for the Pi Camera on a Core XY printer. I use this adapter https://shop.pimoroni.com/products/pi-camera-hdmi-cable-extension to conver to HDMI then used this HDMI lead https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B00I3HKK52/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1 to join them.

You may also consider getting a short USB A to B cabe if you mount the Pi on the frame like I have, this cable will do if this is the case https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B00FQGWBYQ/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1. I also use https://shop.pimoroni.com/products/3-in-1-camera-lens-set lens set for better overall table vision even though the final video is slightly out of focus.

Use Octoprint for PC'less printing.

title: Make #9 - Jingle Bells
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
"... Jingle bell rock; Jingle bells swing, and Jingle bells ring; Snowing and blowing up bushels of fun; Now the jingle hop has begun..."
Print out and ring in the Season with these fun little bells! This clever design incorporates a working print-in-place Clapper- way more fun than another whistle ;) Faberdashery are releasing daily, seasonal designs for you to print and enjoy. Join in the fun with our 25 Days of Making! This is Make #9 of 25.

Slice with 2 shells (/perimeters) and 0% infill. At coarse resolution (0.3mm), you will find prints have extra shimmer (and print quicker!).
Created in stunning Faberdashery Bling Bling Gold PLA^. Each bell requires ~4g of material (<1m of 3mm / 1.75mm filament). Because of the small features (internal clapper), we suggest printing multiple bells to allow sufficient cooling per layer. A classic Ring-of-Bells plated version is provided. You may need to carefully poke a pin through the sides to release the clapper. Just attach some decorative twine to finish.

title: New Years Clover with Pig, hidden numbers
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A shamrock might not be a four leaf clover, but it's close enough :-)

A simple design, intended to be printed at half size(!), it should take only about 10 minutes to print.

If you use transparent filament, the numbers should be visible if held against a light source. (Actually, even opaque filament will be thin enough to see the numbers :-)

If you want to have different colors, use the split version - just prop the pig/head on the clover and all done.
(Make only one at first, to check it really fits - I'm using a .6 nozzle, so it might not fit as well for you.)

[edit]I changed the split version to use a shorter, wider connector. The idea is to allow other items to be put on top (like a ladybug, for example, which isn't as high as the pig).

Printer:

Wanhao i3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Notes:

Reduce size to half to get a nice quick trinket that prints quick enough to be "mass" produced.

At full size it might be something to put against a wall or so?

I've more or less successfully printed 9 at a time. (Clover and pig separately)

You might need to trim the ears and eyes a bit.

Since they're so small and at the top, the printer is likely to leave some threads there.

Can you guess it? I used Tinkercad :-)

It's a simple enough design. Took the shamrock, aligned the pig in the middle, sunk it so far its feet were merged to the shamrock, then aligned a number-hole in each leaf.

(On the way to that I tried to incorporate a horseshoe, without luck, tried to enhance the pig "features" without much luck, etc...)

title: Universal Cable Wrapper
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A cable wrapper / holder for wrapping up cables into small bundles that leave both ends accessible. It is compatible with all standard size charging cables, and is designed to prevent unraveling and tangling.

2017/03/11 UPDATE: Version 2 of the Cable Wrapper is out! It is uploaded as wrapper_v2_5mm. It is slightly larger, no longer has any sharp edges, and is stiffer. v2 is compatible with all cables compatible with the v1. Recommend printing with 30% infill to reduce bending.

Usage

Slide one end of a cable into one of the pointed slots and wrap the other end repeatedly around the wrapper. When satisfied with the length, tuck the other end under the coiled cable and into the opposite pointed slot.

title: HDD wall mount bracket for AB manual backup system

description.text:
I have a hot swap port on my computer a devised a system where I have would two HDD's, A and B, where in one month, i would plug A in and back up, then the next month i would plug in B.

I devised this to store them in a way where i would know which one to grab from backup to backup. one you push one in, it'll pop the one to be used next out a bit, indicating it is to be used.

Yes, I know there are better ways to go about backing up. I simply wanted a way to back up that would be safe from a lot of threats including power surges. this also makes sure if one drive is bad or a virus stuck around for over a month, that i would still have a solution. Again, not the best but i like it!

author: prichey

description.text:
This is a smooth, fast, beautiful egg, based loosely on kellyegan's original.

Improvements:

  • instead of stacking cylinders, this calculates a complete 3D polyhedron shape
  • higher polygon density around both ends of the egg so that it avoids the "pointy tip" phenomenon
  • no rendering artifacts in preview mode. Because the egg is one solid object, there are no rendering artifacts when viewing the inside of an egg (e.g. when removing portions of an egg, as in a hollow egg).
  • much faster at rendering. Using a polyhedron (solid shape) is instantaneously rendered in OpenSCAD (both Preview and Render).
  • uniform distribution of (mostly) square-shaped polygons on the surface creates an appealing surface when printed

description.text:
I made the Original Yamashita Ken MDF Pencil Holder and love it.
But at the Lab, I have an increasingly large collection of writing apparatus.
So I remixed the original desing to be made out of 4.5mm Russian Birch Plywood.
It look nice and is very sturdy. I suggest you oil it before assembly.

Thanks Ken!

Made on a Trotec Speedy 300 @ Fab Lab Museum J.A. Bombardier
my casing broke drilling it so i made a new one. fits anet A8 radial fan
